awd_abstract_narration:
This research project concerns eigenvalues, which represent the characteristic frequencies of oscillation of physical systems, as well as resonances, which are complex numbers generalizing eigenvalues that represent systems where energy can escape and thus oscillation is accompanied by decay. An example of the resonance phenomenon is the sound we hear after striking a bell: it has a frequency of oscillation (the tone) and a rate of decay (how soon we stop hearing the sound), which both depend on the shape of the bell. The frequency and the decay rate that we hear correspond to the real and imaginary part of the least-decaying resonance of the bell. Eigenvalues and resonances have innumerable applications in physics and engineering. A major goal of this project is to understand how the distribution of eigenvalues and resonances depends on the system (for example, how the shape of the bell determines how long it will sound); while this topic has seen recent progress, there remain many important open questions. The project includes research projects for graduate students and numerical experiments for undergraduate students. 

The project employs microlocal analysis, which is the mathematical theory explaining the classical/quantum, or particle/wave, correspondence. For instance, the high-energy distribution of resonances in the simplest model of a bell is related to the classical dynamical system of billiard ball trajectories inside the bell: for bounded times, waves approximately propagate along billiard ball trajectories. However, for long times this approximation becomes worse and eventually breaks down. An especially interesting situation is when the classical system has chaotic behavior; the implications for eigenfunctions and resonances are studied in the field of quantum chaos. Part of the project is centered around the fractal uncertainty principle, which is a new tool beyond the classical/quantum correspondence, established through use of harmonic analysis, fractal geometry, and combinatorics. The fractal uncertainty principle has already seen several applications, including progress towards the conjecture that all strongly chaotic open systems have exponential wave decay. Another part of the project is the study of classical, or Pollicott-Ruelle, resonances, using microlocal methods -- a rare example of the reversal of the classical/quantum correspondence.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The broad goals of this project were to better understand the interplay between classical chaotic systems (where a small perturbation of the initial state causes rapid divergence of the trajectory at later times) and the corresponding quantum systems, both by using classical chaotic theories to study quantum chaotic eigenfunctions/pure states and by using the tools from the quantum world to study classical chaos. The PI and his students and collaborators have advanced significantly on these goals, including:

  • Obtaining several new results on support of semiclassical measures, showing that pure quantum states of a chaotic system have to spread out in the high energy limit. This in particular brings the techniques introduced by the PI and collaborators to higher dimensional problems.
  • In connection with the previous point, proving a fractal uncertainty principles in higher dimensions, showing that a quantum wave function cannot localize simultaneously in position and momentum to a fractal set. This greatly extends the range of applications of fractal uncertainty principle, which has previously been restricted to one-dimensional cases.
  • Understanding the connection between the Ruelle zeta function, an object inspired by the Riemann zeta function and associated to closed orbits of a given classical chaotic system, and the topology of the underlying phase space of that system.
  • Bringing the methods used in quantum chaos to the study of forced waves in effectively 2-dimensional water tanks, in particular giving a mathematically rigorous explanation for the experimentally discovered presence of attractors there.

As part of the project, the PI and his collaborators have completed 6 research papers. The graduate students working with the PI have completed 7 research papers.

The project has reached many educational goals:

  • The PI has mentored 4 graduate students and 1 postdoctoral researcher.
  • The PI has coauthored a book on mathematical scattering resonances, which presents recent advances in this field (many of which are related to both classical and quantum chaos) to a broad audience including graduate and undergraduate students. This book has already become a standard reference on the topic and according to Google Scholar it has been cited 558 times.
  • The PI has written a set of lecture notes on distribution theory which he committed to have published as a textbook with Springer.
  • The PI has developed a new graduate level course on chaotic dynamics at MIT, in addition to co-developing an introductory undergraduate course on proofs.
  • The PI has co-organized 3 conferences/workshops aiming in particular at introducing early career researchers to recent advances in analysis, differential equations, and dynamical systems, and co-organized 2 summer schools aimed entirely at educating graduate students and postdoctoral researchers.
  • The PI has given 6 minicourses aimed at graduate and undergraduate students on various topics related to the project.
